_prev_prog_3.Description: WITH PUBLIC RECEPTORS WITH THE DISTANCE TO AN ENDPOINT FROM A WORST CASE RELEASE AND BEING SUBJECT TO OSHA'S PSM STANDARD THE RESULT IS HGP BEING ASSIGNED A PROGRAM 3 PROCESS

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Holden Gas Processing (HGP) facility, located in Logan County West Virginia, is a refrigerated JT (Joules-Thompson) effect plant designed to process 8 MMscfd of gas at an inlet pressure of 45 psig and 60?F.  The facility was moved to its present location in late 1999 from Huntsville, Tennessee.  The compression was brought on-line in January 2000.  The process was brought on line March 2000. The facility is manned 10 hours daily. 

Low pressure inlet gas from CHK?s gathering system is delivered to the plant via a 10? pipeline between 25-45 psig.  The gas is compressed by 3 electric drive reciprocating gas compressors to process pressure of approximately 900 psig.  The gas is dehydrated using Tri-ethylene Glycol (TEG) and Molecular Sieve prior to entering the liquid extractions portion of the process.  The TEG system produces an effluent stream (primarily water) that is pumped to a slop tank. 

The nature of the plant is gas expansion from a higher pressure to a lower pressure, thereby cooling the gas to extract hydrocarbon liquids and making the resulting residue gas merchantable The plant is designed to operate in the de-ethanizing mode. Overhead vapors (residue gas) from the de-ethanizer with a volume of 7.5 MMscfd and composition of 76% Methane and 15% Ethane are recompressed to 1150 psig and delivered to the Columbia Gas Transmission Pipeline.  Liquids leaving the bottom of the de-ethanizer flow to the fractionation system. 

Depropanizer and Debutanizer fractionation systems are provided at HGP.  The facility produces a approximately 1200-1500 gallons a day of Propane product with a composition of 10% Ethane and 75% Propane.  The balance of the product stream is composed of heavy ends.

The facility produces approximately 3000 gallons a day of a Butanes plus (Propane/Butane mix) product stream with a composition of  21% Propane, 41% Butane and 20% Pentane.  The balance of the fluid mix are heavy ends commonly known as C6 plus. 

Ethane Propane, Butane and

Pentane are regulated substances each with a TQ of 10,000 lbs.

Because of the volume of stored regulated substances vs. the transient gas stream, only the storage area was evaluated when determining RMP eligibility or Program level.  The interconnecting piping would make the refrigeration plant part of the "process" but the requirements would not change in relation to distance to the overpressure endpoint of 1 psi or resulting RMP Program level.

There are five (5) 30,000 gallon pressurized ?bullet? type storage tanks on location.  

Two (2) of the storage tanks are used primarily for propane storage.  One tank is produced into daily.  When the tank is full @ 85% the tanks are switched.  The full tank is vented back into the process to reduce the ethane content before being trucked from the facility.

One (1) tank is used for Butanes Plus (Propane-Butane mix) storage.  This tank is shipped by truck as soon as a load (9,500 gallons) is produced.  Though this tank is procedurally held at approximately 33%, at 3,000 gallons production a day, if transportation were unavailable, the tank could fill to 88% maximum in 5.5 days.  Consequently, the tank was evaluated as being full.

One (1) tank is used as a slop tank.  As discussed above, the effluent stream from the TEG dehydrator is pumped to this tank.  Additional fluids from the various tanks are dumped in the tank.  The normal content of this vessel is 98% water. This fluid is transported by truck to an offsite disposal facility.

One (1) tank remains in standby mode.  This tank can be used for either Propane or Butane storage if for some reason (weather) transportation was unavailable for shipping the product. Procedurally, this tank is used only as standby and as such was not evaluated for RMP.

Worst Case and Alternate Release Scenarios

We used RMP*Comp? and two composition scenarios to determine worst case scenario.  The first was as:
?    two (2)- 30,000 gallon propane tanks at 88% full (maximum level allowable un

der NFPA-58 at 60 F) multiplied by 4.224 lbs per/gallon = 223,027 lbs 
?    one (1) -30,000 gallon Butanes plus tank at 88% full multiplied by 4.8414 lbs/gal (an average of Propane, Butane and Pentane)= 127,813 lbs 
?    TOTAL = 350,840 lbs
We also calculated a mixture of flammable substance stream as:
?    Ethane as 10% of two (2)- 30,000 gallon propane tanks at 88% full multiplied by 4.224 lbs per/gallon = 22,303 lbs
?    Propane as 90% of two (2)- 30,000 gallon propane tanks at 88% full multiplied by 4.224 lbs per/gallon + 21.2% of one (1) -30,000 gallon Butanes plus tank at 88% full multiplied by 4.224 lbs/gal  = 224,365 lbs
?    Butane as one (1) -30,000 gallon Butanes plus tank at 88% full multiplied by 4.8414 lbs/gal (an average of Propane, Butane and Pentane) less 20% (9.5801% iso-pentane(@ 5.194 gal/lb)  and 11.73 % n-pentane (@5.248 gal/lb) )Pentane (29,388 lbs) and 21.2% Propane (23,641lbs) multiplied by 4.224 lbs/gal  = 74,784 lbs     
?    Pentane as 20% of one (1) -30,000 gallon Butanes plus tank at 88% full multiplied by 9.5801% iso-pentane @ 5.194 gal/lb  and 11.73 % n-pentane @5.248 gal/lb = 29,388 lbs
?    TOTAL = 350,840 lbs
These both gave us a worst case scenario (Worst Case assumes the entire contents were released and formed a vapor cloud which detonated) distance to the overpressure endpoint of 1 psi of 0.6 miles.  There are approximately 30 homes with an estimated 90 residents within the 0.6 mile radius of HGP.
The Alternate release scenario involves a Pull-Away explosion of a driver failing to remove the hoses while loading propane.  This scenario involves a release of the entire contents of the hose (2? x 20?) of 3.3 gallons and the contents of the piping from the tank to the hose (3? x 120?)of 44.1 gallons multiplied  by 4.224= ~200 lbs.  The scenario estimates a release of ? a minute before the active mitigation system (excess flow valves) stop the flow.  This gave us an alternate case scenario distance to the overpressure endpoint of 1 psi of 0.05miles.  There

are no homes within the 0.0mile radius of HGP.

Five Year Accident History

There have been no accidents with specific offsite consequences at HGP in the past five years
Program Level

With public receptors within the distance to an endpoint from a worst case release and being subject to OSHA?s PSM standard, the result is HGP being assigned a Program 3 process.
Accidental Release Prevention Program
HGP is subject to OSHA 29 CFR 1910.119 Process Safety Management for Highly Hazardous Chemicals(PSM)..  The PSM program was implemented prior to the facility being moved to West Virginia

HGP is also subject to EPA?s 40 CFR 112.7 Spill Prevention Countermeasures and Control standard.  An SPCC is in place to establish procedures to prevent contain and control a hydrocarbon release.

HGP complies with NFPA standard 58.

In the unlikely event of a fire at HGP, employees may respond to an incipient stage fire and then must evacuate the facility.  An Emergency Action Plan developed to 29 CFR 1910.38(a) is in place to establish procedures for the safe evacuation of the facility and summon emergency response organizations. HGP has coordinated response with the Cora Fire Department.  Members of the fire department have inspected the liquid storage system.
